verbs.description: uncowl (third-person singular simple present uncowls, present participle uncowling, simple past and past participle uncowled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To divest or deprive of a cowl (monk's hood or hooded robe).
examples: Can the pope, to say nothing of himself and his cardinals, do away with his four archbishops and ninety-eight bishops? Will he reduce the prodigious number of his priests, who muster as strong as one twenty-eighth of the population? Will he uncowl his monks, two thousand and twenty-three of whom swarm about the streets of Rome alone?

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative, archaic) To uncover; to unveil.
examples: I pray you, think us friends—uncowl your face,
For you seem faint, and the night-breeze blows healing.

entries.meaning: (instransitive) To remove or pull back one's cowl.
examples: “Monseigneur, it is not often your capuchin uncowls; least of all when he wishes to remain unknown!  […] ”

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove the cowl (protective covering) from (an engine).
examples: […]  uncowling the airplane before each flight is neither practical nor expected. In fact, uncowling such an airplane repeatedly may wear the latching or fastening devices.
